articles.headline: Survey Says: Never Tweet
articles.snippet: The tensions in newsrooms over reporters’ social media presence are not just about politics.
articles.abstract: The tensions in newsrooms over reporters’ social media presence are not just about politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Carr, the legendary Timesman who made this column a destination, told me back in 2012 that he kept a “helicopter on the roof” of The New York Times Building in case he needed to escape. After all, he had been taking shots at media moguls, including, occasionally, his own bosses. That helicopter, he said, was his Twitter account, and it gave him the power, if needed, to flee The Times and take his followers — more than 300,000 when he died in 2015.

articles.headline: Gensler Faces Big Challenge in Tackling GameStop’s Wild Ride
articles.snippet: There is broad agreement that the capital markets have been distorted but less consensus on what, if anything, the S.E.C. should do about it.
articles.abstract: There is broad agreement that the capital markets have been distorted but less consensus on what, if anything, the S.E.C. should do about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During his last regulatory stint in Washington, Gary Gensler focused on reining in big Wall Street players that he believed were manipulating markets and assuming huge financial positions to the detriment of other investors.

articles.headline: $500 Billion in Aid to Small Businesses: How Much Did It Help?
articles.snippet: Some economists say the Paycheck Protection Program has not proved as useful as other aid. The debate could sway the new administration’s plans.
articles.abstract: Some economists say the Paycheck Protection Program has not proved as useful as other aid. The debate could sway the new administration’s plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Democrats and Republicans spent months last fall arguing over how to rescue the economy, one provision drew widespread support from lawmakers: reviving the Paycheck Protection Program, the government’s marquee effort to help small businesses weather the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Worker Deaths Put Big Tech in China Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The deaths of two young employees of Pinduoduo, an e-commerce platform, have reignited longstanding concerns about working conditions at internet giants.
articles.abstract: The deaths of two young employees of Pinduoduo, an e-commerce platform, have reignited longstanding concerns about working conditions at internet giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was 1:30 a.m. just days before the new year, and the 22-year-old employee of Pinduoduo, a Chinese e-commerce company, was leaving after a long day of work. Suddenly, she clutched her stomach and collapsed. Her co-workers rushed her to a hospital, but six hours later, she died.

articles.headline: An Emboldened Extremist Wing Flexes Its Power in a Leaderless G.O.P.
articles.snippet: As more far-right Republicans take office and exercise power, party officials are promoting unity and neutrality rather than confronting dangerous messages and disinformation.
articles.abstract: As more far-right Republicans take office and exercise power, party officials are promoting unity and neutrality rather than confronting dangerous messages and disinformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Knute Buehler, who led Oregon’s Republican ticket as the candidate for governor in 2018, watched with growing alarm in recent weeks as Republicans around the nation challenged the reliability of the presidential election results.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Mike Baker

articles.headline: The ‘Dr. Fauci’ of the Texas Border Is Counting the Dead
articles.snippet: Laredo, Texas, is enduring the country’s worst outbreak at the end of the pandemic’s deadliest month. A crusading cardiologist, leading the fight, is begging the state to close down his city.
articles.abstract: Laredo, Texas, is enduring the country’s worst outbreak at the end of the pandemic’s deadliest month. A crusading cardiologist, leading the fight, is begging the state to close down his city.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Texas — Each day at around 6 p.m., Dr. Ricardo Cigarroa goes through the same grim ritual. He sits at his desk and counts the dead.

articles.headline: $500 billion in aid to small businesses: How much did it help?
articles.abstract: As Democrats and Republicans spent months last fall arguing over how to rescue the economy, one provision drew widespread support from lawmakers: reviving the Paycheck Protection Program, the government’s marquee effort to help small businesses weather the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Democrats and Republicans spent months last fall arguing over how to rescue the economy, one provision drew widespread support from lawmakers: reviving the Paycheck Protection Program, the government’s marquee effort to help small businesses weather the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Silver Rises With Hype It’s the Next GameStop, but a Backlash Mutes Gains
articles.snippet: The precious metal jumped 11.5 percent to its highest level in eight years, then gave up some of its gains as some online investors smelled a trap.
articles.abstract: The precious metal jumped 11.5 percent to its highest level in eight years, then gave up some of its gains as some online investors smelled a trap.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the frantic price swings of companies like GameStop and AMC Entertainment tantalized the financial world last week, everyone wondered what the army of internet investors would set its sights on next.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Matt Phillips
